content: meeting in 4 minutes!
@T-release meeting!
Seems like just us :smile:
ok, looks like not too many people today :)
the main thing I wanted to bring up is the release blog post situation - I am expecting to write at least this cycle's
I’m going to have the relnotes up by Monday.
thanks, that sounds great

I've also been thinking about the general problem -- one of the things that I came up with is that it's actually quite hard to find things for most of our recent posts, and we do highlight things, but those are largely 'small things', rather than really notable additions. I've been thinking that it may be best to alter how we write release blog posts to reduce the amount of highlighting we do, both to make it more special when we do it, and also to (hopefully) help with the feeling that rust is always changing
I also talked with Steve about this yesterday and generally we both seemed optimistic about this strategy; I'm planning to collaborate there on an RFC to this effect
isn't that evident in how we talk already? e.g. 1.50 was pretty brief, and 1.51 had a lot more depth, and I don't think that was just our different writing styles
well, sort of, but right now we still try to pull out something
this proposal would be that e.g. maybe 1.50 would not have highlighted anything (I forget what was in that release), instead be a more standard 'just a release is out' with no additional content.
I think there's some analysis to do and to fine tune this idea still, and I'd love to chat with folks who have suggestions/thoughts -- happy to discuss during our friday meetings as well.
I like highlighting something for contributor's sake
you add something small, and it might get called out (if not overshadowed)
I'm not sure how to feel about not having any mention of features on smaller releases

I think there may be alternative opportunities to do that, but I definitely think orienting around that, rather than highlighting particular additions because we think they're 'major' or something is more likely to be the right fit.
I don’t know if I like that. I agree it can be a lot of effort to do that kind of editorial work, but I think a release that didn’t talk a bit about what’s in it would be unsatisfying for users.
didn't think about it too hard, but could it be possible to turn smaller things from full sections of the post to a relnotes-style section? like we do with library changes
this would still provide content for smaller releases and would prevent completly shadowing small things for bigger releases

I think it may make sense to let this ruminate a bit and we can continue discussing next week - part of the reason I suggest this is that we have relatively speaking struggled to find a consistent author in the long run. (Which is understandable, given our bandwidth etc, but it is the reality).
I think a relnotes style section may indeed work.
In any case, still very early days to be clear :)
ok, @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
oh, actually
mostly I'm curious why you mentioned an RFC for this
it seems... overkill? :smile:
I think it's a good way to get community feedback and drive discussion?
I'm wondering if that's the right channel, as that's more frequented by contributors or people deeply invested in the project
it's not like we have a formal procedure for writing these in the first place
maybe URLO could be a better place to ask for feedback? it should have more of the population we (are? want to?) aim the blog post to
Well, regardless, the doc itself seems good to write up as at least for me that helps assess the idea
and we can ask TWIR to feature it similar to an RFC to drive more traffic to it
definitely!
that's all from me
identifying where to post it and how to get that feedback -- I think a users post and maybe even a mention inthe 1.52 blog post (or whatever the next one is) may be good avenues. :)
ok, sounds good
@DPC was there anything to highlight from wg-triage?

it's not like we have a formal procedure for writing these in the first place

To that point however, I would like us to create some “how to write release post” docs on forge. At least to make it easier for non regulars to feel like they can participate.
nothing much, had the usual meeting on wednesday where most of it was taking updates on the dashboard, other minor changes to triagebot
sure, I just don't want to get too prescriptive on content
ok - in that case, it sounds like that's about it, @triagebot end-meeting ?

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
@cuviper Yeah, I don’t mean style guide-esque “how to write” more like “here are the steps”.
all right, thanks all!
